text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Saturday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- President Hosni Mubarak to hold talks with Sultan Qaboos bin Said today. The two leaders will discuss Arab affairs and bilateral relations. Egyptian ambassador to Muscat says the talks will open new horizons for cooperation between the two countries.

- Public Enterprise Minister Atef Obeid tells editors from the Wall Street Journal: Egypt's economic reform programme has surpassed the expectations of the International Monetary Fund and the climate is now set for an economic boom.
- Middle East mediator Osama el-Baz continues his mission in Israel next week. A report by the U.N. secretary general confirms the danger of settlement building in Jabal Abu Ghneim.
- More students to be admitted into universities this year.
- Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa will take part in the Hong Kong handover celebrations.

- Mubarak to review investment projects in Sinai and the New Valley. Widescale cabinet meeting to discuss a comprehensive report on the two areas. The private sector has an essential role to play in developing the areas.
- Amr Moussa says: Egypt's efforts to restart the Middle East peace process are based on the land-for-peace formula.
- UAE President Sheikh Zaid bin Sultan al-Nahayan sends Mubarak a letter.
- The popularity of Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has fallen to its lowest level ever.
- Tourism Minister Mamdouh el-Beltagi contributes to international "White Book" of tourism, tells the world about Egypt's experience in developing the industry.
